stream_context.summary: Kaze designs and tests the retro "Board the Platforms" section for Return to Yoshi's Island, live-streaming simultaneously on Twitch and YouTube while refining background visuals, platform layout, and camera behaviour.

development_findings.summary: Sixteen distinct floor surface types (grass, water, stone, creaky woods, snow, sand, ice, mud, wood, steel, glass, leaves, squishy, grates) are now implemented, each with unique flags for sound and physics.
The outside of Oily Boily Bay is complete and enormous; sand shows footstep impressions and Badub has written its music.
development_findings.quote: You can even make floor steps in the sand, and we already have songs for all these areas from Badub.

development_findings.summary: Current task is a 3-D remake of Smash 64’s "Board the Platforms" as the area’s 8-bit bonus level; future retro stages are planned for Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, and Super Mario Land 1.
Background solution: three layers of semi-transparent coloured squares are distributed on a sphere and rotated at different speeds/directions to mimic Smash 64 while minimising overdraw.
development_findings.quote: It's gonna look like a high-quality version of this.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a custom Geo ASM rotation node exported via Fast64; debugged parent-lookup and order-of-operations issues until each layer rotated correctly.
Performance decisions: chose individual squares instead of a single scrolling texture to avoid four-times overdraw; monitored segment memory and culled unused objects.
Fixed a stray triangle artifact caused by a lava-bubble object spawning inside a pipe.
Prototyped platform layout with four branching paths and moving lifts; iteratively resized platforms to balance difficulty for Course 11.
Adjusted d-pad camera logic: lowered acceleration and raised base velocity so taps give fine adjustment yet can still function as main rotation.
Outlined the last four main course themes: Wild West Valley (bounty bosses), Music-themed or Yoshi School level (undecided), Oversized Casino, and Comic-book City with superhero Mario.
Target release remains 2024 but is not guaranteed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze returned to Twitch because he found an ad-blocker and now uses Restream to reach both audiences, valuing viral reach.
context_findings.quote: The reason I went back to Twitch is I found an ad blocker.

context_findings.summary: He and Zeina recently moved into a house that doubles as a home gym with a large Yoshi collection wall.
Balances the hack with a full-time job at Gears for Breakfast; streams only on Saturdays.
Enjoys weightlifting (benching 242 lb plus bar) and discusses equipment quirks like a permanently bent bar.
Had a nightmare about accidentally breaking an NDA and being interrogated by Gus Fring, showing anxiety about professional obligations.
States a personal communication philosophy: speech should be precise and concise; also enjoys cheap technical tricks to impress on N64 hardware.

biobak.summary: Appears in chat; Kaze praises the new redesign and consults him on art-related matters.

badub.summary: Has delivered music tracks for all current areas; Kaze calls them "bangers."

zeina.summary: Confirmed Twitch stream was working; Kaze notes certain stream rewards (‘cum shake’) only redeemable when she is present.

key_stories.title: Multistream Comeback
key_stories.summary: Kaze had abandoned Twitch because of intrusive ads but wanted broader engagement. After discovering an effective ad blocker he tested Restream to broadcast to both platforms simultaneously.
key_stories.challenge: Re-establish a Twitch presence without suffering ads and manage two audiences at once.
key_stories.process: Installed ad blocker, configured Restream, monitored chat delay and performance during the live session.
key_stories.outcome: Stream reached ~100 combined viewers and Kaze plans to keep the dual setup.
key_stories.key_quote: This is the coolest effect ever… I think the dual setup works for me.

key_stories.title: Smash-Style Skybox Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Early attempts at recreating the Smash 64 square skybox looked flat and blurry. Kaze redesigned it using three rotating layers of transparent squares generated from a high-poly sphere.
key_stories.challenge: Match the iconic backdrop while staying within N64 performance limits.
key_stories.process: Prototyped cubes vs spheres, debated overdraw costs, created Geo ASM rotation nodes, fixed rotation-direction and render-order bugs.
key_stories.outcome: Achieved a faithful, performant skybox that he calls "really good looking."
key_stories.key_quote: We’re gonna have one layer… then another… so it’s gonna look like a high-quality version of this.

key_stories.title: Live Camera Tuning
key_stories.summary: Viewers felt small d-pad nudges were too slow, prompting on-stream adjustments.
key_stories.challenge: Provide both precise micro-adjustment and usable main rotation in the same control.
key_stories.process: Tweaked base velocity and acceleration values in code, re-compiled, and demonstrated new feel live.
key_stories.outcome: Committed a new curve to test, telling chat he’d keep it if feedback stays positive.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe it’s better, maybe not. If not, then unlucky.
